data: Which one of the following is the most appropriate definition of a 99% confidence interval?

A 99% confidence interval indicates that in 99 out of 100 samples taken, the interval will contain the true value of the parameter being estimated. This definition aligns with the concept of confidence intervals in statistics.
What is the main difference between the Dickey Fuller (DF) and Phillips-Perron (PP) approaches to unit root testing?

The main difference between the Dickey Fuller (DF) and Phillips-Perron (PP) approaches to unit root testing lies in the fact that ADF is a single equation approach to unit root testing while PP is a systems approach.
If there were a leverage effect in practice, what would be the shape of the news impact curve for as model that accounted for that leverage?

If there is a leverage effect present, it means that negative disturbances have a stronger impact than positive disturbances of the same magnitude. Therefore, the news impact curve would rise more quickly for negative disturbances than for positive ones of the same magnitude.
Which of the following statements is false concerning the linear probability model?
The statement that the error terms will be heteroscedastic and not normally distributed is false as the linear probability model assumes homoscedastic error terms and normally distributed errors.
Which of the following statements concerning the regression population and sample is FALSE?
If the sample is larger than the population, then it is not a sample, it is actually representing the population itself. Therefore, the statement C is false.
Which of the following statements is INCORRECT concerning a comparison of the Box-Pierce Q and the Ljung-Box Q* statistics for linear dependence in time series?

The statement that is incorrect regarding the comparison of Box-Pierce Q and Ljung-Box Q* statistics is that as the sample size tends towards infinity, both tests will show a tendency to always reject the null hypothesis of zero autocorrelation coefficients. This statement is not true as the correct statement is that both tests, as the sample size tends towards infinity, will follow asymptotic distributions where they have power against a wide range of alternatives, not just the null hypothesis.
A parsimonious model is one that
A parsimonious model is a model that includes as few variables as possible to explain the data. This type of model aims to balance simplicity and explanatory power.
Which of the following is NOT a feature of continuously compounded returns (i.e. log-returns)?
Continuously compounded returns are known for being normally distributed, not fat-tailed. Therefore, the statement that continuously compounded returns are usually fat-tailed is incorrect.

Which of the following features of financial asset return time-series could be captured using a standard GARCH(1,1) model?

i) Fat tails in the return distribution


ii) Leverage effects


iii) Volatility clustering


iv) Volatility affecting returns

A standard GARCH(1,1) model is commonly used to capture features such as volatility clustering (iii) and volatility affecting returns (iv). However, it does not inherently account for fat tails in the return distribution (i) or leverage effects (ii).

Consider the estimation of a GARCH-M model. If the data employed were a time-series of daily corporate bond percentage returns, which of the following would you expect the value of the GARCH-in-mean parameter estimate to be?

In a GARCH model, the GARCH-in-mean parameter captures the effect of volatility on the mean of the returns. For daily corporate bond percentage returns, we would expect this parameter estimate to be positive since higher volatility typically leads to higher expected returns. Therefore, we would expect the value of the GARCH-in-mean parameter estimate to be between 0 and 1.

Under which of the following situations would bootstrapping be preferred to pure simulation?

i) If it is desired that the distributional properties of the data in the experiment

are the same as those of some actual data


ii) If it is desired that the distributional properties of the data in the experiment

are known exactly


iii) If the distributional properties of the actual data are unknown


iv) If the sample of actual data available is very small

Bootstrapping is preferred when the distributional properties of the data are either unknown or if the sample size is very small. In those situations, bootstrapping can help generate estimates and inferences without assuming a specific distribution.

Which of the following may be consequences of one or more of the CLRM assumptions being violated?

i) The coefficient estimates are not optimal


ii) The standard error estimates are not optimal


iii) The distributions assumed for the test statistics are inappropriate


iv) Conclusions regarding the strength of relationships between the dependent

and independent variables may be invalid.

When one or more of the CLRM assumptions are violated, it can lead to suboptimal coefficient estimates, suboptimal standard error estimates, inappropriate test statistic distributions, and invalid conclusions about the relationships between variables. Therefore, all the consequences mentioned are possible when assumptions are violated.
Which of the following statements is true concerning forecasting in econometrics?
Mis-specified models are likely to produce inaccurate forecasts because if the model does not accurately represent the data generating process, the forecasts will be unreliable.
The pacf is necessary for distinguishing between

The partial autocorrelation function (pacf) is necessary for distinguishing between an AR and an MA model. The pacf helps to identify the direct relationship between two variables after removing the effect of other variables.
Negative residual autocorrelation is indicated by which one of the following?

Negative residual autocorrelation means that there is a pattern in the residuals that indicates a relationship between consecutive residuals. A cyclical pattern in the residuals would suggest a negative residual autocorrelation.

Which of the following statements are true concerning a comparison between ARCH(q) and GARCH(1,1) models?

i) The ARCH(q) model is likely to be the more parsimonious


ii) The ARCH(q) model is the more likely to violate non-negativity constraints


iii) The ARCH(q) model can allow for an infinite number of previous lags of squared

returns to affect the current conditional variance


iv) The GARCH(1,1) model will usually be sufficient to capture all of the dependence

in the conditional variance

In general, the GARCH(1,1) model is considered to be more parsimonious than the ARCH(q) model because it specifies the conditional variance based on only the first lag of the squared errors, while the ARCH(q) model can involve an infinite number of lags. The ARCH(q) model is more likely to violate non-negativity constraints because there is no restriction on the coefficients in the ARCH(q) model while the GARCH(1,1) model has constraints (alpha and beta) that ensure the conditional variance is non-negative. Therefore, the correct statements are (i), (ii), and (iii), as the GARCH(1,1) model is not sufficient to capture all the dependence in the conditional variance.

Which of the following statements are true concerning a triangular or recursive system?

i) The parameters can be validly estimated using separate applications of OLS to

each equation


ii) The independent variables may be correlated with the error terms in other

equations


iii) An application of 2SLS would lead to unbiased but inefficient parameter estimates


iv) The independent variables may be correlated with the error terms in the equations

in which they appear as independent variables

Statement ii) and iv) are correct because in triangular or recursive systems, the independent variables may indeed be correlated with the error terms in other equations as well as in the equations in which they appear as independent variables. Statement i) is incorrect because the parameters cannot be validly estimated using separate applications of OLS to each equation in such systems. Statement iii) is incorrect because an application of 2SLS would not lead to unbiased parameter estimates in this context.
Which one of the following statements best describes the algebraic representation of the fitted regression line?

The correct representation of the fitted regression line typically includes the intercept term (\hat{\alpha}) and the slope coefficient (\hat{\beta}), along with the error term (\hat{u}_t). This is shown in option A: \hat{y}_t = \hat{\alpha} + \hat{\beta}x_t + \hat{u}_t.

When we multiply a column vector $\hat{u}$ by its transpose, we get a square matrix with dimensions equal to the length of the vector. Since $\hat{u}$ is a column vector with dimensions k x 1, the product $\hat{u}^t \hat{u}$ will have dimensions k x k.

The characteristic roots of the MA process

$y_t = -3u_{t-1} + u_{t-2} + u_t$

are

The characteristic roots of an MA(2) process are the solutions to the equation $1 + \theta_1z + \theta_2z^2 = 0$, where $\theta_1$ and $\theta_2$ are the parameters of the model. In this case, the MA process is given by $y_t = -3u_{t-1} + u_{t-2} + u_t$. By comparing it to the general MA(2) process, we can see that $\theta_1 = -3$ and $\theta_2 = 1$. Solving the quadratic equation $1 - 3z + z^2 = 0$ gives us the characteristic roots $z_1 = 2$ and $z_2 = -1$. Therefore, the characteristic roots of the MA process are 2 and -1, which corresponds to option C.
Which of the following is an equivalent expression for saying that the explanatory variable is "non-stochastic"?

If the explanatory variable is "non-stochastic," it means that it is not subject to randomness and remains constant across different samples. This aligns with the idea that the explanatory variable is fixed in repeated samples, as it does not vary or change randomly.

Suppose that the Durbin Watson test is applied to a regression containing two explanatory variables plus a constant with 50 data points. The test statistic takes a value of 1.53. What is the appropriate conclusion?
The Durbin-Watson test statistic falls between 0 and 2. A value of 1.53 is closer to the lower boundary of 0, indicating that there may be positive autocorrelation present in the residuals.

If OLS is used in the presence of autocorrelation, which of the following will be likely consequences?

i) Coefficient estimates may be misleading


ii) Hypothesis tests could reach the wrong conclusions


iii) Forecasts made from the model could be biased


iv) Standard errors may inappropriate

Autocorrelation violates one of the Gauss-Markov assumptions, leading to biased and inconsistent estimates of the coefficients. This can lead to misleading coefficient estimates, incorrect hypothesis tests, and biased forecasts. However, standard errors are not directly affected by autocorrelation.
What will be the properties of the OLS estimator in the presence of multicollinearity?

In the presence of multicollinearity, the OLS estimator will still be unbiased, but it will not be efficient. This is because multicollinearity increases the variance of the OLS estimator, affecting its efficiency while leaving its unbiasedness intact.
Which one of the following would NOT be a consequence of using non-stationary data in levels form?

When dealing with non-stationary data in levels form, the consequence that would NOT occur is that the regression \( R^2 \) may be spuriously high. Non-stationary data typically leads to a lower \( R^2 \) value as the data points are not independent.
If a series, y, follows a random walk, what is the optimal one-step ahead forecast of y?
In a random walk model, the best one-step ahead forecast of y is its current value because random walk models assume that the best estimate for the future value of y is its most recent value.

The order condition in econometrics is a necessary but not sufficient condition for identification. It specifies the number of instrumental variables needed for identification, but additional conditions are required to ensure identification.
If an estimator is said to have minimum variance, which of the following statements is NOT implied?
If an estimator has minimum variance, it is not guaranteed to always be unbiased. An estimator can have minimum variance without being unbiased.

Which of the following are disadvantages of the Dickey-Fuller / Engle-Granger approach to testing for cointegration and modelling cointegrating relationships?

i) Only one cointegrating relationship can be estimated

ii) Particularly for small samples. There is a high chance of the tests suggestingthat variables are not cointegrated when they are

iii) It is not possible to make inferences on the cointegrating regression

iv) The procedure forces the researcher to specify which is the dependent variable and which are the independent variables.

Option (i) states that only one cointegrating relationship can be estimated, which is a disadvantage. Option (ii) highlights that there is a high chance of the tests suggesting variables are not cointegrated when they are, particularly for small samples. Option (iii) mentions that it is not possible to make inferences on the cointegrating regression. Option (iv) states that the procedure forces the researcher to specify the dependent and independent variables, which is a limitation. Therefore, all the listed disadvantages are valid, making option D the correct answer.
Which of the following statements is true concerning the population regression function (PRF) and sample regression function (SRF)?

The population regression function (PRF) represents the true relationship between the independent and dependent variables in the entire population, while the sample regression function (SRF) is an estimated model based on a sample drawn from the population. Therefore, the correct statement is that the PRF is a description of the process thought to be generating the data.
Which one of the following is a disadvantage of the general to specific or "LSE" ("Hendry") approach to building econometric models, relative to the specific to general approach?

The disadvantage of the general to specific approach is that if the initial model is mis-specified, all subsequent steps will be invalid as the model is built on incorrect assumptions in the first stage.

Which of the following statements are true concerning maximum likelihood (ML) estimation in the context of GARCH models?

i) Maximum likelihood estimation selects the parameter values that maximise the

probability that we would have actually observed the values of the series y that we

actually did.


ii) GARCH models can only be estimated by ML and not by OLS


iii) For estimation of a standard linear model (with no GARCH), the OLS and ML

estimates for the slope and intercept parameters will be identical but the estimator

for the variance of the disturbances is slightly different


iv) Most computer packages use numerical procedures to estimate GARCH models

rather than a set of analytical formulae

i) is true as maximum likelihood estimation aims to maximize the likelihood of observing the data.
ii) is false as GARCH models can also be estimated using other methods such as Bayesian estimation.
iii) is true for standard linear models as OLS and ML estimates will be the same for the slope and intercept parameters, but the estimator for the variance of disturbances will be different.
iv) is true as most software packages use numerical procedures to estimate GARCH models due to their complexity.

Therefore, the correct answer is D as all statements (i), (ii), (iii), and (iv) are true concerning maximum likelihood estimation in the context of GARCH models.
Including relevant lagged values of the dependent variable on the right hand side of a regression equation could lead to which one of the following?

Including relevant lagged values of the dependent variable on the right-hand side of a regression equation could lead to biased but consistent coefficient estimates. This is because the inclusion of lagged values can introduce endogeneity issues, which causes the coefficient estimates to be biased. However, if the bias is the same across different samples, the estimates are still consistent.
Which one of the following factors is likely to lead to a relatively high degree of out-of-sample forecast accuracy?

A model that is based on financial theory is likely to lead to a relatively high degree of out-of-sample forecast accuracy because it incorporates theoretical principles and relationships that are expected to hold true in the future. This can help the model better predict outcomes beyond the data it was trained on.

Which of the following are plausible approaches to dealing with residual autocorrelation?

i) Take logarithms of each of the variables

ii) Add lagged values of the variables to the regression equation

iii) Use dummy variables to remove outlying observations

iv) Try a model in first differenced form rather than in levels.

Residual autocorrelation can be addressed by adding lagged values of the variables to the regression equation (ii) and trying a model in first differenced form rather than in levels (iv). Taking the logarithms of the variables (i) and using dummy variables to remove outlying observations (iii) do not directly address residual autocorrelation.
For an autoregressive process to be considered stationary

For an autoregressive process to be considered stationary, the roots of the characteristic equation must all be less than one in absolute value. This ensures that the process does not exhibit explosive behavior.

Which of the following statements are true concerning information criteria?

(i) Adjusted R-squared is an information criterion

(ii) If the residual sum of squares falls when an additional term is added, the value of the information criterion will fall

(iii) Akaike's information criterion always leads to model orders that are at least as large as those of Schwarz's information criterion

(iv) Akaike's information criterion is consistent

Adjusted R-squared is not an information criterion, so statement (i) is incorrect. If the residual sum of squares falls when an additional term is added, the value of the information criterion will indeed fall, making statement (ii) correct. Akaike's information criterion does not always lead to model orders that are at least as large as those of Schwarz's information criterion, so statement (iii) is incorrect. Akaike's information criterion is consistent, making statement (iv) true. Therefore, the correct answer is A. (ii) and (iv) only.

The "within transform" typically refers to the process of subtracting the mean of each entity (individual, group, etc.) from each observation on that entity. This method helps in removing individual effects from the data, allowing for a more accurate analysis of the variation across entities.
The purpose of "augmenting" the Dickey-Fuller test regression is to

The purpose of "augmenting" the Dickey-Fuller test regression is to take into account all the non-stationarity in the data, which is done by adding additional lags of the dependent variable in the regression model.
If a series, y, follows a random walk with drift b, what is the optimal one-step ahead forecast of the change in y?

In a random walk with drift, the optimal one-step ahead forecast of the change in y is equal to the drift term (b) because the change in y is expected to continue in the direction of the drift. Therefore, the correct answer is not A (The current value of y), not B (Zero), and not D (The average value of the change in y over the in-sample period). The correct answer is C (One), which represents the drift term in a random walk with drift.

Which of the following are plausible approaches to dealing with a model that exhibits heteroscedasticity?

i) Take logarithms of each of the variables

ii) Use suitably modified standard errors

iii) Use a generalised least squares procedure

iv) Add lagged values of the variables to the regression equation.

Heteroscedasticity refers to the situation where the variance of the errors in a regression model is not constant. To deal with this issue, suitable options include taking the logarithms of each of the variables (i), using suitably modified standard errors (ii), and using a generalized least squares procedure (iii). Adding lagged values of the variables to the regression equation (iv) is not typically a method used to address heteroscedasticity. Therefore, the correct answer is C. (i), (ii), and (iii) only.

Which of the following statements are true concerning the standardised residuals (residuals divided by their respective conditional standard deviations) from an estimated GARCH model?

i) They are assumed to be normally distributed


ii) Their squares will be related to their lagged squared values if the GARCH model is

appropriate


iii) In practice, they are likely to have fat tails


iv) If the GARCH model is adequate, the standardised residuals and the raw residuals

will be identical

i) They are assumed to be normally distributed - This statement is not necessarily true, as the normality assumption is about the residuals themselves, not the standardized residuals.

ii) Their squares will be related to their lagged squared values if the GARCH model is appropriate - This is a characteristic of GARCH models, indicating that this statement is true.

iii) In practice, they are likely to have fat tails - This is a common observation in financial data and is often associated with the presence of outliers and extreme events, making this statement true.

iv) If the GARCH model is adequate, the standardized residuals and the raw residuals will be identical - This statement is incorrect as the standardization process alters the residuals to have a mean of zero and unit conditional variance.

Therefore, the correct statements are (ii) and (iii) only.
Which one of the following statements is true concerning VARs?

VARs (Vector Autoregressions) do not require the components to be stationary before being used for forecasting, making option D incorrect. Option C is also not always true as the accuracy of forecasts can vary depending on the specific model and data used. Option A is not always the case as the coefficient estimates in VARs may not always have intuitive theoretical interpretations. This leaves us with option B as the correct statement, where the coefficient estimates typically have the same sign for all of the lags of a given variable in a given equation.
Which of the following statements is INCORRECT concerning the classical hypothesis testing framework?

The incorrect statement concerning the classical hypothesis testing framework is that if the null hypothesis is rejected, the alternative is accepted. In hypothesis testing, one can only reject or fail to reject the null hypothesis; the alternative hypothesis is not explicitly accepted based on the results of the test.
An ARMA(p,q) (p, q are integers bigger than zero) model will have

In an ARMA(p,q) model, the AutoCorrelation Function (ACF) will decline geometrically after p lags, while the Partial AutoCorrelation Function (PACF) will decline geometrically after q lags. Therefore, the correct answer is C. An acf that declines geometrically and a pacf that is zero after q lags.

Suppose that the following regression is estimated using 27 quarterly observations:

$y_t = \beta_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + \beta_3 x_{3t} + u_t$

What is the appropriate critical value for a 2-sided 5% size of test of $H_0: \beta_3 = 1$?

The appropriate critical value for a 2-sided 5% test is 1.96. This is because for a 5% significance level and a two-tailed test, we need to find the value at which 2.5% of the distribution is in each tail. This corresponds to 95% confidence level, which has a critical value of 1.96 in a standard normal distribution.

Suppose that two researchers, using the same 3 variables and the same 250 observations on each variable, estimate a VAR. One estimates a VAR(6), while the other estimates a VAR(4). The determinants of the variance-covariance matrices of the residuals for each VAR are 0.0036 and 0.0049 respectively. What is the values of the test statistic for performing a test of whether the VAR(6) can be restricted to a VAR(4)?

The test statistic for performing a test of whether the VAR(6) can be restricted to a VAR(4) is calculated as \( \left( \frac{{n-k_1-k_2}}{2} \right) \times \ln \left( \frac{{\text{determinant\_VAR1}}}{{\text{determinant\_VAR2}}} \right) \), where \( n \) is the number of observations, \( k_1 \) and \( k_2 \) are the lag orders, and determinant_VAR1 and determinant_VAR2 are the determinants of the variance-covariance matrices. Plugging in the values, we get \( \left( \frac{{250-6-4}}{2} \right) \times \ln \left( \frac{{0.0036}}{{0.0049}} \right) = 77.07 \).
Which of the following is a DISADVANTAGE of using pure time-series models (relative to structural models)?
Pure time-series models may not be theoretically motivated because they rely solely on past data patterns without considering the underlying structure or relationships in the data.

Which of the following are alternative names for the dependent variable (usually denoted by y) in linear regression analysis?

(i) The regressand

(ii) The regressor

(iii) The explained variable

(iv) The explanatory variable

In linear regression analysis, the dependent variable (y) is also known as the regressand, the explained variable, and the dependent variable. The correct answer is therefore (iii), (ii), and (iv) only.

Which of the following are advantages of the VAR approach to modelling the relationship between variables relative to the estimation of full structural models?

i) VARs receive strong motivation from financial and economic theory


ii) VARs in their reduced forms can be used easily to produce time-series forecasts


iii) VAR models are typically highly parsimonious


iv) OLS can be applied separately to each equation in a reduced form VAR

The advantages of the VAR approach are that they can easily produce time-series forecasts using reduced forms and OLS can be applied to each equation separately in a reduced form VAR. Additionally, VARs are not necessarily highly parsimonious and do not always receive strong motivation from financial and economic theory.
Which of the following statements is TRUE concerning the standard regression model?

The correct statement concerning the standard regression model is that y has a probability distribution. In the standard regression model, the dependent variable (y) is assumed to have a probability distribution which is typically normal.

Consider the following model for $y_t$:

$y_t = \mu + \lambda t + u_t$

Which one of the following most accurately describes the process for $y_t$?

The given model is $y_t = \mu + \lambda t + u_t$, where $u_t$ is a random shock term. This model represents a random walk with drift, as it has a deterministic trend component ($\mu + \lambda t$) and a random shock component ($u_t$).
Which of the following is correct concerning logit and probit models?
The correct statement concerning logit and probit models is that the probit model is based on a cumulative logistic function.
What is the most important disadvantage of the diagonal VECH approach to building multivariate GARCH models that is overcome by the BEKK formulation?

The most important disadvantage of the diagonal VECH approach is that it does not ensure a positive-definite variance-covariance matrix. The BEKK formulation, on the other hand, addresses this issue by ensuring positive definiteness of the covariance matrix.

If a relevant variable is omitted from a regression equation, the consequences would be that:

i) The standard errors would be biased


ii) If the excluded variable is uncorrelated with all of the included variables, all of

the slope coefficients will be inconsistent.


iii) If the excluded variable is uncorrelated with all of the included variables, the

intercept coefficient will be inconsistent.


iv) If the excluded variable is uncorrelated with all of the included variables, all of

the slope and intercept coefficients will be consistent and unbiased but inefficient.

If a relevant variable is omitted from a regression equation, the consequences are that the standard errors would be biased (i), the slope coefficients will be inconsistent (ii), and the intercept coefficient will be inconsistent (iii). However, the omission of an irrelevant variable that is uncorrelated with all included variables will lead to all slope and intercept coefficients being consistent and unbiased but inefficient (iv). Therefore, the correct answer is D.

Which of the following are alternative names for the independent variable (usually denoted by x) in linear regression analysis?

(i) The regressor

(ii) The regressand

(iii) The causal variable

(iv) The effect variable

In linear regression analysis, the independent variable is also known as the regressor. Additionally, it can also be referred to as the causal variable. Therefore, the correct answer is B. (i) and (iii) only.

Consider the OLS estimator for the standard error of the slope coefficient. Which of the following statement(s) is (are) true?

(i) The standard error will be positively related to the residual variance

(ii) The standard error will be negatively related to the dispersion of the observations on the explanatory variable about their mean value

(iii) The standard error will be negatively related to the sample size

(iv) The standard error gives a measure of the precision of the coefficient estimate.

The correct statements are (ii) and (iv). The standard error of the slope coefficient will be negatively related to the dispersion of the observations on the explanatory variable about their mean value, as this helps in estimating the slope coefficient more accurately. Additionally, the standard error gives a measure of the precision of the coefficient estimate, indicating how much we can trust the calculated coefficient value.
What is the meaning of the term "heteroscedasticity"?

Heteroscedasticity refers to the situation where the variance of the errors in a regression model is not constant across all levels of the independent variables. Therefore, the correct meaning is that the variance of the errors is not constant, which corresponds to option A.
If a Durbin Watson statistic takes a value close to zero, what will be the value of the first order autocorrelation coefficient?

The Durbin Watson statistic measures the presence of autocorrelation in the residuals of a regression analysis. If the Durbin Watson statistic takes a value close to zero, it indicates a strong positive autocorrelation. In this case, the first order autocorrelation coefficient would be close to plus one.
Under the null hypothesis of a Bera-Jarque test, the distribution has
The null hypothesis of a Bera-Jarque test assumes that the data follows a normal distribution. In a normal distribution, the skewness is zero and the kurtosis is three.
If an estimator is said to be consistent, it is implied that

Consistency of an estimator implies that as the sample size increases, the estimates will converge upon the true values. This means that the estimator will provide results closer to the true parameter values as more data is gathered.
Which of the following is a typical characteristic of financial asset return time-series?

Financial asset return time-series are often characterized by being highly autocorrelated, meaning that the value at a particular time is dependent on the values observed at previous time points. This autocorrelation is a key characteristic often observed in financial asset return time-series.

Which of the following assumptions are required to show the consistency, unbiasedness and efficiency of the OLS estimator?

i) $E(u_t) = 0$


ii) $\text{Var}(u_t) = \sigma^2$


iii) $\text{Cov}(u_t, u_{t-j}) = 0 \forall j$


iv) $u_t \sim N(0, \sigma^2)$
In order to show the consistency, unbiasedness, and efficiency of the OLS estimator, assumptions i), ii), and iii) are required. Assumption iv) is not necessary for these properties.
Which of the following is a disadvantage of the fixed effects approach to estimating a panel model?

One of the disadvantages of the fixed effects approach is that it can only capture cross-sectional heterogeneity and not temporal variation in the dependent variable. This limitation makes it less flexible compared to other panel data techniques.
Consider an identical situation to that of question 21, except that now a 2-sided alternative is used. What would now be the appropriate conclusion?

In a 2-sided alternative test, the null hypothesis (H0) is rejected if the test statistic falls into either tail of the distribution. Therefore, the correct conclusion would be that H0 is not rejected.
The price of a house is best described as what type of number?

The price of a house is a continuous numerical value that can take on any real number, making it best described as a continuous, quantitative variable, which is characteristic of a continuous number. Therefore, the price of a house is best described as a continuous number, making it a type of "discrete" number.
If a Johansen "trace" test for a null hypothesis of 2 cointegrating vectors is applied to a system containing 4 variables is conducted, which eigenvalues would be used in the test?
In a Johansen "trace" test for a null hypothesis of 2 cointegrating vectors with 4 variables, all the eigenvalues would be used in the test.

Which of the following statements is true concerning variance decomposition analysis of VARs?

i) Variance decompositions measure the impact of a unit shock to each of the variables on the VAR

ii) Variance decompositions can be thought of as measuring the proportion of the forecast error variance that is attributable to each variable

iii) The ordering of the variables is important for calculating impulse responses but not variance decompositions

iv) It is usual that most of the forecast error variance for a given variable is attributable to shocks to that variable

Variance decompositions measure the impact of a unit shock to each of the variables on the VAR (i) and can be thought of as measuring the proportion of the forecast error variance that is attributable to each variable (ii). The ordering of the variables is important for calculating both impulse responses and variance decompositions, not just impulse responses. It is not usual that most of the forecast error variance for a given variable is attributable to shocks to that variable, so statement (iv) is incorrect. Therefore, the correct answer is B. (i) and (iii) only.

Suppose that we have estimated a GARCH model for daily equity returns, and we are interested in producing a 10-day forecast of the volatility (measured by the standard deviation of returns) for use in a value at risk model. How could such a forecast most validly be calculated?

To forecast the volatility for multiple periods in the future using a GARCH model, we need to produce 1-step ahead conditional variance forecasts and iterate this process for the desired number of periods. Taking the square root of the sum of these forecasts is necessary to obtain the standard deviation (volatility) values.

Suppose that the value of $R^2$ for an estimated regression model is exactly zero. Which of the following are true?

i) All coefficient estimates on the slopes will be zero

ii) The fitted line will be horizontal with respect to all of the explanatory variables

iii) The regression line has not explained any of the variability of y about its mean value

iv) The intercept coefficient estimate must be zero.

When the value of $R^2$ is exactly zero, it means that the regression model cannot explain any of the variability in the dependent variable. Therefore, the correct statements are ii) The fitted line will be horizontal with respect to all of the explanatory variables and iii) The regression line has not explained any of the variability of y about its mean value. The other statements are not necessarily true in this scenario.

A white noise process will have

(i) A zero mean

(ii) A constant variance

(iii) Autocovariances that are constant

(iv) Autocovariances that are zero except at lag zero

A white noise process is defined as a sequence of uncorrelated random variables with a mean of zero and constant variance. Therefore, it will have a zero mean (i), constant variance (ii), and autocovariances that are zero except at lag zero (iv). Autocovariances that are constant (iii) would not apply to a white noise process.

Which of the following statements are true concerning the Box-Jenkins approach to diagnostic testing for ARMA models?

(i) The tests will show whether the identified model is either too large or too small

(ii) The tests involve checking the model residuals for autocorrelation, heteroscedasticity, and non-normality

(iii) If the model suggested at the identification stage is appropriate, the acf and pacf for the residuals should show no additional structure

(iv) If the model suggested at the identification stage is appropriate, the coefficients on the additional variables under the overfitting approach will be statistically insignificant

The correct statements are (ii) and (iii) only. The Box-Jenkins approach involves checking the model residuals for autocorrelation, heteroscedasticity, and non-normality (statement ii) and if the model suggested at the identification stage is appropriate, the acf and pacf for the residuals should show no additional structure (statement iii). The other statements are not true concerning the diagnostic testing for ARMA models.
Which one of the following would be a plausible response to a finding of residual non-normality?

Residual non-normality can be addressed by transforming the data or changing the model specification. Using a logarithmic functional form instead of a linear one is a common technique to address non-normality in the residuals.
The fixed effects panel model is also sometimes known as

The fixed effects panel model is also known as the least squares dummy variables approach. This approach involves including dummy variables for each individual or group in the panel data set to account for unobserved heterogeneity at that level, making it the correct answer choice here.
Which of the following statements is TRUE concerning OLS estimation?

OLS (Ordinary Least Squares) estimation is a method used in linear regression to find the line that minimises the sum of the squared vertical distances from the data points to the line. This is done by finding the line that minimises the sum of the squared residuals (vertical distances). Therefore, the correct statement is B: OLS minimises the sum of the squares of the vertical distances from the points to the line.

If the standard tools for time-series analysis, such as estimation of the acf, pacf and spectral analysis, find no evidence of structure in the data, this implies that the data are which of the following?

If the standard tools for time-series analysis indicate no evidence of structure in the data, it implies that the data are uncorrelated. This is because the tools used for analyzing time-series data focus on identifying relationships and patterns within the data, and if no structure is found, it suggests that there is no correlation between the observations.

If two variables, $x_t$ and $y_t$ are said to be cointegrated, which of the following statements are true?

i) $x_t$ and $y_t$ must both be stationary


ii) Only one linear combination of $x_t$ and $y_t$ will be stationary


iii) The cointegrating equation for $x_t$ and $y_t$ describes the short-run relationship

between the two series


iv) The residuals of a regression of $y_t$ on $x_t$ must be stationary

If two variables are cointegrated, it means there is a long-run relationship between them, and this relationship is the result of a linear combination ensuring that the combination is stationary. Hence, statement (ii) regarding the linear combination and statement (iv) regarding the residuals being stationary are true. However, cointegration does not necessarily mean both variables are stationary, so statement (i) is incorrect. Also, the cointegrating equation describes the long-run, not short-run, relationship between the two series, making statement (iii) incorrect as well.

A dependent variable whose values are not observable outside a certain range but where the corresponding values of the independent variables are still available would be most accurately described as what kind of variable?

In this case, the variable is still available within a certain range but not observable outside of that range, which fits the definition of a truncated variable. Truncated variables are limited in their range of values due to restrictions or limitations in the data collection process.
A Hausman test would be used for

A Hausman test is used to determine whether the estimates obtained from two different estimators are consistent. Therefore, the correct answer is A because it is used to determine whether an equation that is part of a simultaneous equation system is identified.
Under the matrix notation for the classical linear regression model, $y = X \beta + u$, what are the dimensions of $u$?

In the classical linear regression model, the error term u is a vector of length T (number of observations), where each element represents the difference between the actual value of the dependent variable y and the predicted value based on the independent variables X. Therefore, the dimensions of u would be T x 1.
How many parameters will be required to be estimated in total for all equations of a standard form, unrestricted, tri-variate VAR(4), ignoring the intercepts?

In a tri-variate VAR(4) model, each equation will have 3 endogenous variables, and for each equation, we need to estimate coefficients for each endogenous variable for 4 lags. Therefore, the total number of parameters to be estimated will be 3 * 3 * 4 = 36, ignoring the intercepts.

A researcher tests for structural stability in the following regression model:

$y_t = \beta_1 + \beta_2 x_{2t} + \beta_3 x_{3t} + u_t$

The total sample of 200 observations is split exactly in half for the sub-sample regressions. Which would be the unrestricted residual sum of squares?
When testing for structural stability in a regression model, the unrestricted residual sum of squares refers to the RSS for the whole sample, as the model is estimated without any constraints.

Suppose that we are interested in testing the null hypothesis that a GARCH(2,2) model can be restricted to a process with a constant conditional variance using the likelihood ratio test approach. Which of the following statements are true?

The correct statement is that the test statistic will follow a chi-squared distribution with 2 degrees of freedom under the null hypothesis for the likelihood ratio test of a GARCH(2,2) model being restricted to a process with constant conditional variance.
Which one of the following is NOT a plausible remedy for near multicollinearity?

Using principal components analysis, dropping one of the collinear variables, and taking logarithms of the variables are all common ways to address near multicollinearity issues. However, using a longer run of data is not a plausible remedy for near multicollinearity as it does not directly address the issue of high correlation between independent variables.

Consider the following AR(2) process:

yt = 1.5 yt-1 - 0.5 yt-2 + ut

This is a

An AR(2) process is stationary if the roots of the characteristic equation lie outside the unit circle. In this case, the characteristic equation is 1 - 1.5z + 0.5z^2 = 0. The roots are z = 2 and z = 0.5, both of which lie outside the unit circle, indicating a stationary process.
Which of the following could be used as a test for autocorrelation up to third order?

The test that could be used as a test for autocorrelation up to third order is the Breusch-Godfrey test. This test extends the Durbin-Watson test by including higher order autocorrelation up to the desired lag.
The residual from a standard regression model is defined as
The residual is calculated as the difference between the actual value (y) and the fitted value (y-hat) from the regression model.
If OLS is applied separately to each equation that is part of a simultaneous system, the resulting estimates will be

When OLS is applied separately to each equation in a simultaneous system, the resulting estimates will be biased but consistent. This is because OLS assumes that the error terms are uncorrelated with the independent variables, which is unlikely to hold in a simultaneous equation system where the error terms are likely to be correlated across equations.
Which one of the following is NOT an example of mis-specification of functional form?

Using a linear specification when a double-logarithmic model would be more appropriate is an example of mis-specification of functional form. However, excluding a relevant variable from a linear regression model is not related to mis-specification of functional form but rather variable selection bias.

Suppose that we wished to evaluate the factors that affected the probability that an investor would choose an equity fund rather than a bond fund or a cash investment. Which class of model would be most appropriate?

A multinomial logit model would be the most appropriate in this scenario because it allows for the evaluation of factors that influence the selection among multiple discrete choices (equity fund, bond fund, or cash investment). This type of model is specifically designed for situations where the dependent variable has more than two categories.

Which of the following statements will be true if the number of replications used in a Monte Carlo study is small?

i) The statistic of interest may be estimated imprecisely


ii) The results may be affected by unrepresentative combinations of random draws


iii) The standard errors on the estimated quantities may be unacceptably large


iv) Variance reduction techniques can be used to reduce the standard errors

When the number of replications used in a Monte Carlo study is small, the results may indeed be affected by unrepresentative combinations of random draws (ii) and variance reduction techniques may be less effective due to the limited number of replications (iv). The statistic of interest may still be estimated imprecisely (i), and the standard errors on the estimated quantities could be unacceptably large (iii). Therefore, the correct answer is D.
Which of the following is a disadvantage of the random effects approach to estimating a panel model?

The random effects approach may not be valid if the composite error term is correlated with one or more of the explanatory variables, as this violates the assumption of the model. Additionally, the random effects approach can capture both cross-sectional and temporal variation in the dependent variable, so option C is incorrect. Option B is also incorrect as the number of parameters to estimate is typically smaller in random effects models compared to fixed effects models.

Which of the following could result in autocorrelated residuals?

i) Slowness of response of the dependent variable to changes in the values of the independent variables

ii) Over-reactions of the dependent variable to changes in the independent variables

iii) Omission of relevant explanatory variables that are autocorrelated

iv) Outliers in the data

Autocorrelated residuals occur when there is a correlation between consecutive residuals in a time series data. Outliers in the data may cause random noise but not necessarily autocorrelation. Slowness of response of the dependent variable to changes in the values of the independent variables and over-reactions of the dependent variable to changes in the independent variables can lead to autocorrelated residuals. Omission of relevant explanatory variables that are autocorrelated would also result in autocorrelated residuals. Therefore, the correct answer is C. (i), (ii), and (iii) only.

Which of the following statements are true concerning the acf and pacf?

(i) The acf and pacf are often hard to interpret in practice

(ii) The acf and pacf can be difficult to calculate for some data sets

(iii) Information criteria represent an alternative approach to model order determination

(iv) If applied correctly, the acf and pacf will always deliver unique model selections

Statement (i) states that the acf and pacf are often hard to interpret in practice, which is true as interpreting these plots can be challenging. Statement (iii) is correct as information criteria can be used as an alternative method for determining the order of a model. However, statement (ii) is incorrect because the acf and pacf are not necessarily difficult to calculate for all data sets; they are standard tools in time series analysis. Additionally, statement (iv) is incorrect because the acf and pacf are not guaranteed to always provide a unique model selection.

Which of the following conditions are necessary for a series to be classifiable as a weakly stationary process?

(i) It must have a constant mean

(ii) It must have a constant variance

(iii) It must have constant autocovariances for given lags

(iv) It must have a constant probability distribution

Weak stationarity requires that the mean, variance, and autocovariances of the series do not depend on time. This means conditions (i), (ii), and (iii) must be satisfied, so the correct answer is C. The constant probability distribution is not a necessary condition for weak stationarity.

Consider the following equation and determine the class of model that it best represents

$y_{it} = \alpha + \beta_{it} + \mu_i + \nu_{it}$

In this equation, the term $\mu_i$ represents the entity-specific fixed effects, and the term $\beta_{it}$ represents the time-varying component. The presence of entity fixed effects suggests that this equation best represents an entity fixed effects model.
Note that statistical tables are not necessary to answer this question. For a sample of 1000 observations, the Dickey-Fuller test statistic values are

The Dickey-Fuller test statistic values are typically compared to critical values to determine statistical significance. The critical values are obtained from tables specific to the Dickey-Fuller distribution and are not related to a normal distribution. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

Suppose that a hypothesis test is conducted using a 5% significance level. Which of the following statements are correct?

(i) The significance level is equal to the size of the test

(ii) The significance level is equal to the power of the test

(iii) 2.5% of the total distribution will be in each tail rejection region for a 2-sided test

(iv) 5% of the total distribution will be in each tail rejection region for a 2-sided test.

The correct statements are (i), (iii), and (iv). 
(i) The significance level is equal to the size of the test, which is true.
(ii) The significance level is not equal to the power of the test, so this statement is incorrect.
(iii) For a 2-sided test with a 5% significance level, 2.5% will be in each tail rejection region, so this statement is correct.
(iv) Similarly, for a 2-sided test with a 5% significance level, 5% will be in total for both tail rejection regions, so this statement is correct.

Therefore, the correct answer is D. (i), (ii), (iii), and (iv).
Which one of the following criticisms of the Dickey-Fuller/Engle-Granger approach to dealing with cointegrated variables is overcome by the Engle-Yoo (EY) procedure?

The Engle-Yoo (EY) procedure addresses the limitation of the Engle-Granger (EG) approach by allowing for the detection of multiple cointegrating relationships, overcoming the criticism that EG can only detect up to one cointegrating relationship.
Consider a series that follows an MA(1) with zero mean and a moving average coefficient of 0.4. What is the value of the autocovariance at lag 1?

For an MA(1) process with a moving average coefficient of 0.4, the autocovariance at lag 1 can be calculated using the formula Cov(Yt, Yt-1) = θ1 * σ^2, where θ1 is the moving average coefficient and σ^2 is the disturbance variance. Since the mean is zero, the variance equals 1. Therefore, Cov(Yt, Yt-1) = 0.4 * 1 = 0.4.

Which of the following estimation techniques are available for the estimation of over-identified systems of simultaneous equations?

i) OLS

ii) ILS

iii) 2SLS

iv) IV

In the context of estimation techniques for over-identified systems of simultaneous equations, 2SLS (Two-Stage Least Squares) and IV (Instrumental Variables) are typically used. OLS stands for Ordinary Least Squares and is not specifically designed for over-identified systems. ILS is not a commonly used estimation technique in this context. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) (iii) and (iv) only.
Which one of the following statements best describes a Type II error?
Type II error occurs when we fail to reject a null hypothesis that is false, meaning we incorrectly accept a false null hypothesis. Therefore, the correct answer is D.
Which one of the following would be the most appropriate as a 95% (two-sided) confidence interval for the intercept term of the model given in question 21?

A 95% confidence interval is typically calculated as the estimate plus or minus the margin of error. Since the intercept term can be positive or negative, the confidence interval should be symmetric around zero. Therefore, the most appropriate option for a 95% confidence interval for the intercept term would be (-1.98, 1.98), which is choice C.

Which of the following are characteristics of a stationary process?

i) It crosses its mean value frequently


ii) It has constant mean and variance


iii) It contains no trend component


iv) It will be stationary in first difference form

A stationary process has constant mean and variance (ii) and contains no trend component (iii). In first difference form, the series will be stationary if it was not stationary in its original form. Therefore, (ii) and (iv) are characteristics of a stationary process.
Consider again the VAR model of equation 16. Which of the following conditions must hold for it to be said that there is bi-directional feedback?

In a VAR model to have bi-directional feedback, both sets of coefficients must be significant, meaning both the lagged values of each variable significantly affect each other. Therefore, the correct condition for bi-directional feedback in a VAR model is for both the a, c and b, d coefficients to be significant.

Consider the following sample autocorrelation estimates obtained using 250 data points:

1) Lag 1 2 3

2) Coefficient 0.2 -0.15 -0.1

3) Assuming that the coefficients are approximately normally distributed, which of the coefficients are statistically significant at the 5% level?

In order to determine the statistical significance at the 5% level, we need to compare the absolute value of each coefficient to the critical value of the normal distribution at 5% significance level. The critical value is approximately 1.96. From the given coefficients, only lag 1 has a coefficient that exceeds the critical value (0.2 > 1.96). Therefore, only lag 1 is statistically significant at the 5% level.
Which one of the following is examined by looking at a goodness of fit statistic?

The goodness of fit statistic is used to determine how well the sample regression function fits the data. It helps to assess the overall quality of the model's fit to the data by measuring how close the observed values are to the predicted values.

Which of the following statements are correct concerning the use of antithetic variates as part of a Monte Carlo experiment?

i) Antithetic variates work by reducing the number of replications required to cover the whole probability space

ii) Antithetic variates involve employing a similar variable to that used in the simulation, but whose properties are known analytically

iii) Antithetic variates involve using the negative of each of the random draws and repeating the experiment using those values as the draws

iv) Antithetic variates involve taking one over each of the random draws and repeating the experiment using those values as the draws

Antithetic variates work by reducing the variance of the estimator in Monte Carlo experiments by using a similar variable (antithetic variate) whose properties are known analytically. Antithetic variates involve creating pairs of values that are negatively correlated, not simply taking the negative of random draws. Therefore, statement ii is correct. Statement iv is incorrect as it suggests taking the reciprocal of random draws, which is not how antithetic variates work. Statement i is incorrect because antithetic variates do not reduce the number of replications required, but rather reduce the variance of the estimator. Statement iii is also incorrect as antithetic variates do not involve using the negative of each random draw.
Which one of the following statements is true concerning alternative forecast accuracy measures?

Mean squared error is commonly used in forecasting and is not necessarily highly correlated with trading rule profitability. Mean absolute error provides a linear loss function, not quadratic. Mean absolute percentage error is a more common measure for evaluating forecasts rather than asset return forecasts. Mean squared error does penalize large forecast errors more than small forecast errors, making option D the correct choice.

Which of the following criticisms of standard ("plain vanilla") GARCH models can be overcome by EGARCH models?

i) Estimated coefficient values from GARCH models may be negative

ii) GARCH models cannot account for leverage effects

iii) The responsiveness of future volatility to positive and negative shocks is symmetric under a GARCH formulation

iv) GARCH models cannot allow for a feedback from the volatility to the returns

A criticism of standard GARCH models is that they cannot account for leverage effects, which can be addressed by EGARCH models. Additionally, GARCH models cannot allow for a feedback from volatility to returns, which EGARCH models can handle. Therefore, the correct answer is A. (ii) and (iv) only.

Suppose that 100 separate firms were tested to determine how many of them "beat the market" using a Jensen-type regression, and it is found that 3 fund managers significantly do so. Does this suggest prima facie evidence for stock market inefficiency?

The fact that only 3 out of 100 fund managers beat the market does not provide enough evidence to conclude that the stock market is inefficient. It is possible that the 3 fund managers simply got lucky or had a unique strategy that worked during the time of the test. To determine market efficiency, a more comprehensive analysis would be required.

Which of the following are advantages of the use of panel data over pure cross-sectional or pure time-series modelling?

(i) The use of panel data can increase the number of degrees of freedom and therefore the power of tests

(ii) The use of panel data allows the average value of the dependent variable to vary either cross-sectionally or over time or both

(iii) The use of panel data enables the researcher allows the estimated relationship between the independent and dependent variables to vary either cross-sectionally or over time or both

Panel data allows for all three advantages mentioned in the options. Panel data increases the number of degrees of freedom and power of tests (i). It also allows the average value of the dependent variable to vary either cross-sectionally or over time or both (ii). Furthermore, panel data enables the estimated relationship between the independent and dependent variables to vary either cross-sectionally or over time or both (iii).
If the Engle-Granger test is applied to the residuals of a potentially cointegrating regression, what would be the interpretation of the null hypothesis?

The Engle-Granger test is used to determine if there is a long-run relationship between two variables (cointegration). Therefore, the interpretation of the null hypothesis in this test is that the variables are not cointegrated.

Which of the following statements are true concerning the autocorrelation function (acf) and partial autocorrelation function (pacf)?

i) The acf and pacf will always be identical at lag one whatever the model

ii) The pacf for an MA(q) model will in general be non-zero beyond lag q

iii) The pacf for an AR(p) model will be zero beyond lag p

iv) The acf and pacf will be the same at lag two for an MA(1) model

i) The statement is incorrect as acf and pacf will not always be identical at lag one whatever the model.
ii) The statement is correct as the pacf for an MA(q) model will in general be non-zero beyond lag q.
iii) The statement is correct as the pacf for an AR(p) model will be zero beyond lag p.
iv) The statement is incorrect as the acf and pacf will not be the same at lag two for an MA(1) model.

Therefore, the correct answer is B. (i) and (iii) only.
